text:
- [Rupesh] Are slow queries
and lengthy analysis processes
hindering your productivity?
Discover OpenSearch Msearch feature
for bulk vector search
optimizing query efficiency
and accelerating response times.
Say goodbye to sluggish analysis
and embrace the data-driven efficiency.
Hi there, I am Rupesh Tiwari,

a senior solutions architect
at Amazon Web Services

specializing in data
analytics and OpenSearch.

Together we will unlock
your data's potential.
So join me on this transformative journey
to revolutionize your analysis
and empower your organization
with confident data-driven decisions.

Let's unleash the power of
OpenSearch bulk vector search
and dive in.
OpenSearch powered by Apache Lucene
is a community-driven, open-source,
full-text search engine.

With OpenSearch Service on
AWS, harness its capabilities
to build scalable cloud applications.
This robust engine enables text analytics

with full-text searches,
aggregations and boolean searches
leveraging the accurate BM25 algorithm.
It goes beyond text analytics
by integrating machine learning tools

for generating and
storing vector embeddings,
enabling semantic and predictive searches.
Unlock advanced data analysis

and search functionalities
with OpenSearch.
Explore the potential

of this community-driven,
open-source solution

combined with AWS scalability
and managed services.
Customers often encounter challenges
when handling large vector data sets
and performing multiple searches

report generation and batch
operation using API calls.

Let's consider a customer who
faced similar difficulties

making 32,000 API calls for
vector search in OpenSearch.

However, this approach
brought significant issues.
Response time increased

leading to performance
degradation, resource exhaustion,
strain CPU, memory and network bandwidth,

network congestions, cost,
package loss, and latency.

Scalability challenges
arose impacting performance
when exceeding systems limit.

They experienced performance
reductions of 30 to 50%.

Despite their attempt to
implement rate limiting
and concurrency management,

they did not achieve
the desired improvements
in performance and stability.

Luckily, OpenSearch
has a surprise for you.
The multi-search API,
it's a game changer in a data retrieval.

Perform multiple searches
in single API call
saving time and boosting performance.

Say goodbye to latency and
unnecessary network traffic.

Bundle your queries with
the Msearch endpoint

and unlock the full potential
of your applications.
OpenSearch multi-search APIs here

to surprise you with
seamless data analysis
and unmatched efficiency.
Get ready to be amazed.

This example highlights the
power of Msearch feature

for bulk k-nearest neighbors,
also known as KNN search.

KNN enables users to find
the k-nearest neighbors
to a query point in a vector index.
By utilizing Msearch endpoint,
we bundle multiple KNN search request
into a single API call.

Customization options
include the vector field,

query vector and number
of nearest neighbors.
Optimize your search process

with Msearch achieving faster
results and reduced overhead.

The API response includes
results from each KNN queries.
Join me for a live demo
where I will showcase the implementation

of Bulk KNN search using
Msearch in OpenSearch.

Let's dive in and unlock the
potential of this feature.

I have already set up an
OpenSearch domain in my AWS account

and access the Dev Tools in
the OpenSearch dashboard.

If you have not created
an OpenSearch domain yet,

I recommend following the AWS
developer guide documentation
to do so.

This will allow you to
follow along with me
and make the most of our session together.
In this demo, I will guide you
through a simplified example of OpenSearch
bulk vector search capabilities.

Please note that this demo
provides a basic understanding

but can be expanded for
large-scale API call handling.
First, I will create an index

with properties named
as vector5 and vector6
forming the foundation for vector search.
After that, I will try to go ahead
and put some data into OpenSearch.
So after ingesting of sample data,
using prices as vector,

we can perform a search
to find the price range
associated with a specific vector value:
two, three, five, six.

And you can notice it
is resulting in a range
of the prices 5.5 and 8.9.

Next, let's explore the
potential of multiple queries
in a single search operation.
OpenSearch Msearch feature

and enables simultaneously
execution of multiple queries.

By specifying the index
name and search parameters

for each query, we can handle
numerous queries efficiently.

So I'm going to execute
the Msearch operation.
So after executing the Msearch operation,

it retrieves the prices
associated with each query.

This demo demonstrates the
efficiency of OpenSearch
in handling both searches
and providing relevant results,

such as the price like 5.5
and 8.9 for the first query,

and the other numbers
for the other queries.
With Msearch, we eliminate the need
for individual API calls in a loop.
Instead, we optimize the search process

by sending a single document
with multiple queries.

Improving efficiency
akin to bulk indexing.

Although this demo showcases
a simplified example,

it's important to note
that the bulk vector search

can handle a significant
number of API calls
in a single operation.
OpenSearch architecture and scalability
allow for high-performance searches
across various real-world scenarios.

I hope this demo has
provided valuable insights

into OpenSearch potential
for bulk vector search.

Thank you for joining
me, and I look forward

to exploring advanced
use cases in the future.

Unlock the potential
of your data with ease
using Amazon OpenSearch Service.
Feel free to reach out to us

if you have any further
questions, comments,
or thoughts, or suggestions.
We are here to support you on your journey
with Amazon OpenSearch Service

and ensure you get the
most out of your data.

Our team is ready to
assist and provide guidance

as you explore the
capabilities of OpenSearch.
So do not hesitate to contact us.

We value your feedback and
are committed to your success.
Thank you.
